graphic.desc: This is the image of the first page of the comedy contained in the First Folio, also known as Mr. William Shakespeare's Comedies, Histories, and Tragedies, written by William Jaggard. It can be found at page 21 of 920 fol. 2A1r.

stage.hi: A tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard .
Enter a Shipmaster and a Boatswain .

sp.speaker: MASTER
sp.l: Boatswain !

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: Here , master . What cheer ?

sp.speaker: MASTER
sp.l: Good , speak to th’ mariners . Fall to ’t yarely ,
or we run ourselves aground . Bestir , bestir !

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: Heigh , my hearts ! Cheerly , cheerly , my
hearts ! Yare , yare ! Take in the topsail . Tend to th’
Master’s whistle . — Blow till thou burst thy wind , if
room enough !

stage.hi: Enter Alonso , Sebastian , Antonio , Ferdinand , Gonzalo , and others .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Good boatswain , have care . Where’s the Master ?
Play the men .

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: I pray now , keep below .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Where is the Master , boatswain ?

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: Do you not hear him ? You mar our labor .
Keep your cabins . You do assist the storm .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Nay , good , be patient .

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: When the sea is . Hence ! What cares these
roarers for the name of king ? To cabin ! Silence !
Trouble us not .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Good , yet remember whom thou hast
aboard .

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: None that I more love than myself . You are
a councillor ; if you can command these elements
to silence , and work the peace of the present , we
will not hand a rope more . Use your authority .
If you cannot , give thanks you have lived so long , and
make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance
of the hour , if it so hap . — Cheerly , good
hearts ! — Out of our way , I say !

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: I have great comfort from this fellow . Methinks
he hath no drowning mark upon him . His
complexion is perfect gallows . Stand fast , good
Fate , to his hanging . Make the rope of his destiny
our cable , for our own doth little advantage . If he be
not born to be hanged , our case is miserable .

stage.hi: He exits with Alonso , Sebastian , and the other courtiers .

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: Down with the topmast ! Yare ! Lower , lower !
Bring her to try wi’ th’ main course .
A plague upon this howling ! They are
louder than the weather or our office .
Yet again ? What do you here ? Shall we give o’er and
drown ? Have you a mind to sink ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: A pox o’ your throat , you bawling , blasphemous ,
incharitable dog !

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: Work you , then .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Hang , cur , hang , you whoreson , insolent
noisemaker ! We are less afraid to be drowned than
thou art .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: I’ll warrant him for drowning , though the
ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky
as an unstanched wench .

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: Lay her ahold , ahold ! Set her two courses .
Off to sea again ! Lay her off !

sp.speaker: MARINERS
sp.l: All lost ! To prayers , to prayers ! All lost !

sp.speaker: BOATSWAIN
sp.l: What , must our mouths be cold ?

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: The King and Prince at prayers . Let’s assist
them , for our case is as theirs .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I am out of patience .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards .
This wide-chopped rascal — would thou
mightst lie drowning the washing of ten tides !

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: He’ll be hanged yet , though every drop of
water swear against it and gape at wid’st to glut him .
“ Mercy on us ! ” — “ We split , we
split ! ” — “ Farewell , my wife and children ! ” —
“ Farewell , brother ! ” — “ We split , we split , we
split ! ”

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Let’s all sink wi’ th’ King .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Let’s take leave of him .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea
for an acre of barren ground : long heath , brown
furze , anything . The wills above be done , but I
would fain die a dry death .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: If by your art , my dearest father , you have
Put the wild waters in this roar , allay them .
The sky , it seems , would pour down stinking pitch ,
But that the sea , mounting to th’ welkin’s cheek ,
Dashes the fire out . O , I have suffered
With those that I saw suffer ! A brave vessel ,
Who had , no doubt , some noble creature in her ,
Dashed all to pieces . O , the cry did knock
Against my very heart ! Poor souls , they perished .
Had I been any god of power , I would
Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere
It should the good ship so have swallowed , and
The fraughting souls within her .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Be collected .
No more amazement . Tell your piteous heart
There’s no harm done .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: O , woe the day !

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: No harm .
I have done nothing but in care of thee ,
Of thee , my dear one , thee , my daughter , who
Art ignorant of what thou art , naught knowing
Of whence I am , nor that I am more better
Than Prospero , master of a full poor cell ,
And thy no greater father .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: More to know
Did never meddle with my thoughts .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: ’Tis time
I should inform thee farther . Lend thy hand
And pluck my magic garment from me .
So ,
Lie there , my art . — Wipe thou thine eyes . Have comfort .
The direful spectacle of the wrack , which touched
The very virtue of compassion in thee ,
I have with such provision in mine art
So safely ordered that there is no soul —
No , not so much perdition as an hair ,
Betid to any creature in the vessel
Which thou heard’st cry , which thou saw’st sink . Sit down ,
For thou must now know farther .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: You have often
Begun to tell me what I am , but stopped
And left me to a bootless inquisition ,
Concluding “ Stay . Not yet . ”

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: The hour’s now come .
The very minute bids thee ope thine ear .
Obey , and be attentive . Canst thou remember
A time before we came unto this cell ?
I do not think thou canst , for then thou wast not
Out three years old .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Certainly , sir , I can .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: By what ? By any other house or person ?
Of anything the image tell me that
Hath kept with thy remembrance .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: ’Tis far off
And rather like a dream than an assurance
That my remembrance warrants . Had I not
Four or five women once that tended me ?

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Thou hadst , and more , Miranda . But how is it
That this lives in thy mind ? What seest thou else
In the dark backward and abysm of time ?
If thou rememb’rest aught ere thou cam’st here ,
How thou cam’st here thou mayst .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: But that I do not .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Twelve year since , Miranda , twelve year since ,
Thy father was the Duke of Milan and
A prince of power .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Sir , are not you my father ?

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Thy mother was a piece of virtue , and
She said thou wast my daughter . And thy father
Was Duke of Milan , and his only heir
And princess no worse issued .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: O , the heavens !
What foul play had we that we came from thence ?
Or blessèd was ’t we did ?

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Both , both , my girl .
By foul play , as thou sayst , were we heaved thence ,
But blessedly holp hither .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: O , my heart bleeds
To think o’ th’ teen that I have turned you to ,
Which is from my remembrance . Please you , farther .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: My brother and thy uncle , called Antonio —
I pray thee , mark me — that a brother should
Be so perfidious ! — he whom next thyself
Of all the world I loved , and to him put
The manage of my state , as at that time
Through all the signories it was the first ,
And Prospero the prime duke , being so reputed
In dignity , and for the liberal arts
Without a parallel . Those being all my study ,
The government I cast upon my brother
And to my state grew stranger , being transported
And rapt in secret studies . Thy false uncle —
Dost thou attend me ?

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Sir , most heedfully .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Being once perfected how to grant suits ,
How to deny them , who t’ advance , and who
To trash for overtopping , new created
The creatures that were mine , I say , or changed ’em ,
Or else new formed ’em , having both the key
Of officer and office , set all hearts i’ th’ state
To what tune pleased his ear , that now he was
The ivy which had hid my princely trunk
And sucked my verdure out on ’t . Thou attend’st not .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: O , good sir , I do .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: I pray thee , mark me .
I , thus neglecting worldly ends , all dedicated
To closeness and the bettering of my mind
With that which , but by being so retired ,
O’erprized all popular rate , in my false brother
Awaked an evil nature , and my trust ,
Like a good parent , did beget of him
A falsehood in its contrary as great
As my trust was , which had indeed no limit ,
A confidence sans bound . He being thus lorded ,
Not only with what my revenue yielded
But what my power might else exact , like one
Who , having into truth by telling of it ,
Made such a sinner of his memory
To credit his own lie , he did believe
He was indeed the Duke , out o’ th’ substitution
And executing th’ outward face of royalty
With all prerogative . Hence , his ambition growing —
Dost thou hear ?

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Your tale , sir , would cure deafness .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: To have no screen between this part he played
And him he played it for , he needs will be
Absolute Milan . Me , poor man , my library
Was dukedom large enough . Of temporal royalties
He thinks me now incapable ; confederates ,
So dry he was for sway , wi’ th’ King of Naples
To give him annual tribute , do him homage ,
Subject his coronet to his crown , and bend
The dukedom , yet unbowed — alas , poor Milan ! —
To most ignoble stooping .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: O , the heavens !

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Mark his condition and th’ event . Then tell me
If this might be a brother .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: I should sin
To think but nobly of my grandmother .
Good wombs have borne bad sons .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Now the condition .
This King of Naples , being an enemy
To me inveterate , hearkens my brother’s suit ,
Which was that he , in lieu o’ th’ premises
Of homage and I know not how much tribute ,
Should presently extirpate me and mine
Out of the dukedom , and confer fair Milan ,
With all the honors , on my brother ; whereon ,
A treacherous army levied , one midnight
Fated to th’ purpose did Antonio open
The gates of Milan , and i’ th’ dead of darkness
The ministers for th’ purpose hurried thence
Me and thy crying self .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Alack , for pity !
I , not rememb’ring how I cried out then ,
Will cry it o’er again . It is a hint
That wrings mine eyes to ’t .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Hear a little further ,
And then I’ll bring thee to the present business
Which now ’s upon ’s , without the which this story
Were most impertinent .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Wherefore did they not
That hour destroy us ?

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Well demanded , wench .
My tale provokes that question . Dear , they durst not ,
So dear the love my people bore me , nor set
A mark so bloody on the business , but
With colors fairer painted their foul ends .
In few , they hurried us aboard a bark ,
Bore us some leagues to sea , where they prepared
A rotten carcass of a butt , not rigged ,
Nor tackle , sail , nor mast ; the very rats
Instinctively have quit it . There they hoist us
To cry to th’ sea that roared to us , to sigh
To th’ winds , whose pity , sighing back again ,
Did us but loving wrong .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Alack , what trouble
Was I then to you !

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: O , a cherubin
Thou wast that did preserve me . Thou didst smile ,
Infusèd with a fortitude from heaven ,
When I have decked the sea with drops full salt ,
Under my burden groaned , which raised in me
An undergoing stomach to bear up
Against what should ensue .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: How came we ashore ?

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: By providence divine .
Some food we had , and some fresh water , that
A noble Neapolitan , Gonzalo ,
Out of his charity , who being then appointed
Master of this design , did give us , with
Rich garments , linens , stuffs , and necessaries ,
Which since have steaded much . So , of his gentleness ,
Knowing I loved my books , he furnished me
From mine own library with volumes that
I prize above my dukedom .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Would I might
But ever see that man .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , standing
sp.l: Now I arise .
Sit still , and hear the last of our sea-sorrow .
Here in this island we arrived , and here
Have I , thy schoolmaster , made thee more profit
Than other princes can , that have more time
For vainer hours and tutors not so careful .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Heavens thank you for ’t . And now I pray you , sir —
For still ’tis beating in my mind — your reason
For raising this sea storm ?

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Know thus far forth :
By accident most strange , bountiful Fortune ,
Now my dear lady , hath mine enemies
Brought to this shore ; and by my prescience
I find my zenith doth depend upon
A most auspicious star , whose influence
If now I court not , but omit , my fortunes
Will ever after droop . Here cease more questions .
Thou art inclined to sleep . ’Tis a good dullness ,
And give it way . I know thou canst not choose .
Come away , servant , come . I am ready now .
Approach , my Ariel . Come .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: All hail , great master ! Grave sir , hail ! I come
To answer thy best pleasure . Be ’t to fly ,
To swim , to dive into the fire , to ride
On the curled clouds , to thy strong bidding task
Ariel and all his quality .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Hast thou , spirit ,
Performed to point the tempest that I bade thee ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: To every article .
I boarded the King’s ship ; now on the beak ,
Now in the waist , the deck , in every cabin ,
I flamed amazement . Sometimes I’d divide
And burn in many places . On the topmast ,
The yards , and bowsprit would I flame distinctly ,
Then meet and join . Jove’s lightning , the precursors
O’ th’ dreadful thunderclaps , more momentary
And sight-outrunning were not . The fire and cracks
Of sulfurous roaring the most mighty Neptune
Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble ,
Yea , his dread trident shake .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: My brave spirit !
Who was so firm , so constant , that this coil
Would not infect his reason ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Not a soul
But felt a fever of the mad , and played
Some tricks of desperation . All but mariners
Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel ,
Then all afire with me . The King’s son , Ferdinand ,
With hair up-staring — then like reeds , not hair —
Was the first man that leaped ; cried “ Hell is empty ,
And all the devils are here . ”

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Why , that’s my spirit !
But was not this nigh shore ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Close by , my master .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: But are they , Ariel , safe ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Not a hair perished .
On their sustaining garments not a blemish ,
But fresher than before ; and , as thou bad’st me ,
In troops I have dispersed them ’bout the isle .
The King’s son have I landed by himself ,
Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs
In an odd angle of the isle , and sitting ,
His arms in this sad knot .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Of the King’s ship ,
The mariners say how thou hast disposed ,
And all the rest o’ th’ fleet .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Safely in harbor
Is the King’s ship . In the deep nook , where once
Thou called’st me up at midnight to fetch dew
From the still-vexed Bermoothes , there she’s hid ;
The mariners all under hatches stowed ,
Who , with a charm joined to their suffered labor ,
I have left asleep . And for the rest o’ th’ fleet ,
Which I dispersed , they all have met again
And are upon the Mediterranean float ,
Bound sadly home for Naples ,
Supposing that they saw the King’s ship wracked
And his great person perish .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Ariel , thy charge
Exactly is performed . But there’s more work .
What is the time o’ th’ day ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Past the mid season .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: At least two glasses . The time ’twixt six and now
Must by us both be spent most preciously .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Is there more toil ? Since thou dost give me pains ,
Let me remember thee what thou hast promised ,
Which is not yet performed me .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: How now ? Moody ?
What is ’t thou canst demand ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: My liberty .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Before the time be out ? No more .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: I prithee ,
Remember I have done thee worthy service ,
Told thee no lies , made no mistakings , served
Without or grudge or grumblings . Thou did promise
To bate me a full year .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Dost thou forget
From what a torment I did free thee ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: No .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Thou dost , and think’st it much to tread the ooze
Of the salt deep ,
To run upon the sharp wind of the North ,
To do me business in the veins o’ th’ Earth
When it is baked with frost .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: I do not , sir .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Thou liest , malignant thing . Hast thou forgot
The foul witch Sycorax , who with age and envy
Was grown into a hoop ? Hast thou forgot her ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: No , sir .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Thou hast . Where was she born ? Speak . Tell me .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Sir , in Argier .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: O , was she so ? I must
Once in a month recount what thou hast been ,
Which thou forget’st . This damned witch Sycorax ,
For mischiefs manifold , and sorceries terrible
To enter human hearing , from Argier ,
Thou know’st , was banished . For one thing she did
They would not take her life . Is not this true ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Ay , sir .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child
And here was left by th’ sailors . Thou , my slave ,
As thou report’st thyself , was then her servant ,
And for thou wast a spirit too delicate
To act her earthy and abhorred commands ,
Refusing her grand hests , she did confine thee ,
By help of her more potent ministers
And in her most unmitigable rage ,
Into a cloven pine , within which rift
Imprisoned thou didst painfully remain
A dozen years ; within which space she died
And left thee there , where thou didst vent thy groans
As fast as mill wheels strike . Then was this island
( Save for the son that she did litter here ,
A freckled whelp , hag-born ) not honored with
A human shape .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Yes , Caliban , her son .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Dull thing , I say so ; he , that Caliban
Whom now I keep in service . Thou best know’st
What torment I did find thee in . Thy groans
Did make wolves howl , and penetrate the breasts
Of ever-angry bears . It was a torment
To lay upon the damned , which Sycorax
Could not again undo . It was mine art ,
When I arrived and heard thee , that made gape
The pine and let thee out .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: I thank thee , master .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: If thou more murmur’st , I will rend an oak
And peg thee in his knotty entrails till
Thou hast howled away twelve winters .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: Pardon , master .
I will be correspondent to command
And do my spriting gently .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Do so , and after two days
I will discharge thee .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: That’s my noble master .
What shall I do ? Say , what ? What shall I do ?

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Go make thyself like a nymph o’ th’ sea . Be subject
To no sight but thine and mine , invisible
To every eyeball else . Go , take this shape ,
And hither come in ’t . Go , hence with diligence !
Awake , dear heart , awake . Thou hast slept well .
Awake .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: The strangeness of your story put
Heaviness in me .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Shake it off . Come on ,
We’ll visit Caliban , my slave , who never
Yields us kind answer .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA , rising
sp.l: ’Tis a villain , sir ,
I do not love to look on .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: But , as ’tis ,
We cannot miss him . He does make our fire ,
Fetch in our wood , and serves in offices
That profit us . — What ho , slave , Caliban !
Thou earth , thou , speak !

sp.speaker: CALIBAN , within
sp.l: There’s wood enough within .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Come forth , I say . There’s other business for thee .
Come , thou tortoise . When ?

stage.hi: Enter Ariel like a water nymph .

sp.l: Fine apparition ! My quaint Ariel ,
Hark in thine ear .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: My lord , it shall be done .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , to Caliban
sp.l: Thou poisonous slave , got by the devil himself
Upon thy wicked dam , come forth !

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: As wicked dew as e’er my mother brushed
With raven’s feather from unwholesome fen
Drop on you both . A southwest blow on you
And blister you all o’er .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: For this , be sure , tonight thou shalt have cramps ,
Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up . Urchins
Shall forth at vast of night that they may work
All exercise on thee . Thou shalt be pinched
As thick as honeycomb , each pinch more stinging
Than bees that made ’em .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I must eat my dinner .
This island’s mine by Sycorax , my mother ,
Which thou tak’st from me . When thou cam’st first ,
Thou strok’st me and made much of me , wouldst give me
Water with berries in ’t , and teach me how
To name the bigger light and how the less ,
That burn by day and night . And then I loved thee ,
And showed thee all the qualities o’ th’ isle ,
The fresh springs , brine pits , barren place and fertile .
Cursed be I that did so ! All the charms
Of Sycorax , toads , beetles , bats , light on you ,
For I am all the subjects that you have ,
Which first was mine own king ; and here you sty me
In this hard rock , whiles you do keep from me
The rest o’ th’ island .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Thou most lying slave ,
Whom stripes may move , not kindness , I have used thee ,
Filth as thou art , with humane care , and lodged thee
In mine own cell , till thou didst seek to violate
The honor of my child .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: O ho , O ho ! Would ’t had been done !
Thou didst prevent me . I had peopled else
This isle with Calibans .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Abhorrèd slave ,
Which any print of goodness wilt not take ,
Being capable of all ill ! I pitied thee ,
Took pains to make thee speak , taught thee each hour
One thing or other . When thou didst not , savage ,
Know thine own meaning , but wouldst gabble like
A thing most brutish , I endowed thy purposes
With words that made them known . But thy vile race ,
Though thou didst learn , had that in ’t which good natures
Could not abide to be with . Therefore wast thou
Deservedly confined into this rock ,
Who hadst deserved more than a prison .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: You taught me language , and my profit on ’t
Is I know how to curse . The red plague rid you
For learning me your language !

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Hagseed , hence !
Fetch us in fuel ; and be quick , thou ’rt best ,
To answer other business . Shrugg’st thou , malice ?
If thou neglect’st or dost unwillingly
What I command , I’ll rack thee with old cramps ,
Fill all thy bones with aches , make thee roar
That beasts shall tremble at thy din .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: No , pray thee .
Aside . I must obey . His art is of such power
It would control my dam’s god , Setebos ,
And make a vassal of him .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: So , slave , hence .

stage.hi: Enter Ferdinand ; and Ariel , invisible , playing and singing .

lg.l: Come unto these yellow sands ,
And then take hands .
Curtsied when you have , and kissed
The wild waves whist .
Foot it featly here and there ,
And sweet sprites bear
The burden . Hark , hark !
Burden dispersedly , within : Bow-wow .
The watchdogs bark .
Burden dispersedly , within : Bow-wow .
Hark , hark ! I hear
The strain of strutting chanticleer
Cry cock-a-diddle-dow .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: Where should this music be ? I’ th’ air , or th’ earth ?
It sounds no more ; and sure it waits upon
Some god o’ th’ island . Sitting on a bank ,
Weeping again the King my father’s wrack ,
This music crept by me upon the waters ,
Allaying both their fury and my passion
With its sweet air . Thence I have followed it ,
Or it hath drawn me rather . But ’tis gone .
No , it begins again .

lg.l: Full fathom five thy father lies .
Of his bones are coral made .
Those are pearls that were his eyes .
Nothing of him that doth fade
But doth suffer a sea change
Into something rich and strange .
Sea nymphs hourly ring his knell .
Burden , within : Ding dong .
Hark , now I hear them : ding dong bell .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: The ditty does remember my drowned father .
This is no mortal business , nor no sound
That the Earth owes . I hear it now above me .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , to Miranda
sp.l: The fringèd curtains of thine eye advance
And say what thou seest yond .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: What is ’t ? A spirit ?
Lord , how it looks about ! Believe me , sir ,
It carries a brave form . But ’tis a spirit .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: No , wench , it eats and sleeps and hath such senses
As we have , such . This gallant which thou seest
Was in the wrack ; and , but he’s something stained
With grief — that’s beauty’s canker — thou might’st call him
A goodly person . He hath lost his fellows
And strays about to find ’em .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: I might call him
A thing divine , for nothing natural
I ever saw so noble .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: It goes on , I see ,
As my soul prompts it . To Ariel . Spirit , fine spirit , I’ll free thee
Within two days for this .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND , seeing Miranda
sp.l: Most sure , the goddess
On whom these airs attend ! — Vouchsafe my prayer
May know if you remain upon this island ,
And that you will some good instruction give
How I may bear me here . My prime request ,
Which I do last pronounce , is — O you wonder ! —
If you be maid or no .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: No wonder , sir ,
But certainly a maid .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: My language ! Heavens !
I am the best of them that speak this speech ,
Were I but where ’tis spoken .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: How ? The best ?
What wert thou if the King of Naples heard thee ?

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: A single thing , as I am now , that wonders
To hear thee speak of Naples . He does hear me ,
And that he does I weep . Myself am Naples ,
Who with mine eyes , never since at ebb , beheld
The King my father wracked .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Alack , for mercy !

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: Yes , faith , and all his lords , the Duke of Milan
And his brave son being twain .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: The Duke of Milan
And his more braver daughter could control thee ,
If now ’twere fit to do ’t . At the first sight
They have changed eyes . — Delicate Ariel ,
I’ll set thee free for this . To Ferdinand . A word , good sir .
I fear you have done yourself some wrong . A word .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Why speaks my father so ungently ? This
Is the third man that e’er I saw , the first
That e’er I sighed for . Pity move my father
To be inclined my way .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: O , if a virgin ,
And your affection not gone forth , I’ll make you
The Queen of Naples .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Soft , sir , one word more .
Aside . They are both in either’s powers . But this swift business
I must uneasy make , lest too light winning
Make the prize light . To Ferdinand . One word more . I charge thee
That thou attend me . Thou dost here usurp
The name thou ow’st not , and hast put thyself
Upon this island as a spy , to win it
From me , the lord on ’t .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: No , as I am a man !

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: There’s nothing ill can dwell in such a temple .
If the ill spirit have so fair a house ,
Good things will strive to dwell with ’t .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , to Ferdinand
sp.l: Follow me .
To Miranda . Speak not you for him . He’s a traitor . To Ferdinand . Come ,
I’ll manacle thy neck and feet together .
Sea water shalt thou drink . Thy food shall be
The fresh-brook mussels , withered roots , and husks
Wherein the acorn cradled . Follow .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: No ,
I will resist such entertainment till
Mine enemy has more power .

stage.hi: He draws , and is charmed from moving .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: O dear father ,
Make not too rash a trial of him , for
He’s gentle and not fearful .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: What , I say ,
My foot my tutor ? — Put thy sword up , traitor ,
Who mak’st a show , but dar’st not strike , thy conscience
Is so possessed with guilt . Come from thy ward ,
For I can here disarm thee with this stick
And make thy weapon drop .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Beseech you , father —

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Hence ! Hang not on my garments .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Sir , have pity .
I’ll be his surety .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Silence ! One word more
Shall make me chide thee , if not hate thee . What ,
An advocate for an impostor ? Hush .
Thou think’st there is no more such shapes as he ,
Having seen but him and Caliban . Foolish wench ,
To th’ most of men this is a Caliban ,
And they to him are angels .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: My affections
Are then most humble . I have no ambition
To see a goodlier man .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , to Ferdinand
sp.l: Come on , obey .
Thy nerves are in their infancy again
And have no vigor in them .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: So they are .
My spirits , as in a dream , are all bound up .
My father’s loss , the weakness which I feel ,
The wrack of all my friends , nor this man’s threats
To whom I am subdued , are but light to me ,
Might I but through my prison once a day
Behold this maid . All corners else o’ th’ Earth
Let liberty make use of . Space enough
Have I in such a prison .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: It works . — Come on . —
Thou hast done well , fine Ariel . — Follow me .
To Ariel . Hark what thou else shalt do me .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA , to Ferdinand
sp.l: Be of comfort .
My father’s of a better nature , sir ,
Than he appears by speech . This is unwonted
Which now came from him .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , to Ariel
sp.l: Thou shalt be as free
As mountain winds ; but then exactly do
All points of my command .

sp.speaker: ARIEL
sp.l: To th’ syllable .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , to Ferdinand
sp.l: Come follow . To Miranda . Speak not for him .

stage.hi: Enter Alonso , Sebastian , Antonio , Gonzalo , Adrian , Francisco , and others .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: Beseech you , sir , be merry . You have cause —
So have we all — of joy , for our escape
Is much beyond our loss . Our hint of woe
Is common ; every day some sailor’s wife ,
The masters of some merchant , and the merchant
Have just our theme of woe . But for the miracle —
I mean our preservation — few in millions
Can speak like us . Then wisely , good sir , weigh
Our sorrow with our comfort .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Prithee , peace .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN , aside to Antonio
sp.l: He receives comfort like
cold porridge .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: The visitor will not give him o’er so .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Look , he’s winding up the watch of his wit .
By and by it will strike .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: Sir —

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: One . Tell .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: When every grief is entertained that’s offered ,
comes to th’ entertainer —

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: A dollar .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Dolor comes to him indeed . You have spoken
truer than you purposed .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you
should .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: Therefore , my lord —

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Fie , what a spendthrift is he of his tongue .

sp.speaker: ALONSO , to Gonzalo
sp.l: I prithee , spare .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Well , I have done . But yet —

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN , aside to Antonio
sp.l: He will be talking .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO , aside to Sebastian
sp.l: Which , of he or Adrian ,
for a good wager , first begins to crow ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: The old cock .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: The cockerel .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Done . The wager ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: A laughter .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: A match !

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: Though this island seem to be desert —

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Ha , ha , ha .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: So . You’re paid .

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible —

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Yet —

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: Yet —

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: He could not miss ’t .

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: It must needs be of subtle , tender , and delicate
temperance .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Temperance was a delicate wench .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Ay , and a subtle , as he most learnedly
delivered .

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: As if it had lungs , and rotten ones .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Or as ’twere perfumed by a fen .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Here is everything advantageous to life .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: True , save means to live .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Of that there’s none , or little .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: How lush and lusty the grass looks ! How
green !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: The ground indeed is tawny .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: With an eye of green in ’t .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: He misses not much .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: No , he doth but mistake the truth totally .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: But the rarity of it is , which is indeed almost
beyond credit —

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: As many vouched rarities are .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: That our garments , being , as they were ,
drenched in the sea , hold notwithstanding their
freshness and gloss , being rather new-dyed than
stained with salt water .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: If but one of his pockets could speak , would
it not say he lies ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Ay , or very falsely pocket up his report .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as
when we put them on first in Afric , at the marriage
of the King’s fair daughter Claribel to the King of
Tunis .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: ’Twas a sweet marriage , and we prosper
well in our return .

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: Tunis was never graced before with such a
paragon to their queen .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Not since widow Dido’s time .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Widow ? A pox o’ that ! How came that “ widow ”
in ? Widow Dido !

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: What if he had said “ widower Aeneas ” too ?
Good Lord , how you take it !

sp.speaker: ADRIAN , to Gonzalo
sp.l: “ Widow Dido , ” said you ? You
make me study of that . She was of Carthage , not of
Tunis .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: This Tunis , sir , was Carthage .

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: Carthage ?

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: I assure you , Carthage .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: His word is more than the miraculous harp .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: He hath raised the wall , and houses too .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: What impossible matter will he make easy
next ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I think he will carry this island home in his
pocket and give it his son for an apple .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: And sowing the kernels of it in the sea , bring
forth more islands .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Ay .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Why , in good time .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: Sir , we were talking that our
garments seem now as fresh as when we were at
Tunis at the marriage of your daughter , who is now
queen .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: And the rarest that e’er came there .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Bate , I beseech you , widow Dido .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: O , widow Dido ? Ay , widow Dido .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: Is not , sir , my doublet as fresh as
the first day I wore it ? I mean , in a sort .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: That “ sort ” was well fished for .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: When I wore it at your daughter’s
marriage .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: You cram these words into mine ears against
The stomach of my sense . Would I had never
Married my daughter there , for coming thence
My son is lost , and , in my rate , she too ,
Who is so far from Italy removed
I ne’er again shall see her . — O , thou mine heir
Of Naples and of Milan , what strange fish
Hath made his meal on thee ?

sp.speaker: FRANCISCO
sp.l: Sir , he may live .
I saw him beat the surges under him
And ride upon their backs . He trod the water ,
Whose enmity he flung aside , and breasted
The surge most swoll’n that met him . His bold head
’Bove the contentious waves he kept , and oared
Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke
To th’ shore , that o’er his wave-worn basis bowed ,
As stooping to relieve him . I not doubt
He came alive to land .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: No , no , he’s gone .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Sir , you may thank yourself for this great loss ,
That would not bless our Europe with your daughter ,
But rather lose her to an African ,
Where she at least is banished from your eye ,
Who hath cause to wet the grief on ’t .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Prithee , peace .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise
By all of us ; and the fair soul herself
Weighed between loathness and obedience at
Which end o’ th’ beam should bow . We have lost your son ,
I fear , forever . Milan and Naples have
More widows in them of this business’ making
Than we bring men to comfort them .
The fault’s your own .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: So is the dear’st o’ th’ loss .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: My lord Sebastian ,
The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness
And time to speak it in . You rub the sore
When you should bring the plaster .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Very well .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: And most chirurgeonly .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: It is foul weather in us all , good sir ,
When you are cloudy .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Foul weather ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Very foul .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Had I plantation of this isle , my lord —

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: He’d sow ’t with nettle seed .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Or docks , or mallows .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: And were the king on ’t , what would I do ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Scape being drunk , for want of wine .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: I’ th’ commonwealth I would by contraries
Execute all things , for no kind of traffic
Would I admit ; no name of magistrate ;
Letters should not be known ; riches , poverty ,
And use of service , none ; contract , succession ,
Bourn , bound of land , tilth , vineyard , none ;
No use of metal , corn , or wine , or oil ;
No occupation ; all men idle , all ,
And women too , but innocent and pure ;
No sovereignty —

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Yet he would be king on ’t .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: The latter end of his commonwealth forgets
the beginning .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: All things in common nature should produce
Without sweat or endeavor ; treason , felony ,
Sword , pike , knife , gun , or need of any engine
Would I not have ; but nature should bring forth
Of its own kind all foison , all abundance ,
To feed my innocent people .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: No marrying ’mong his subjects ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: None , man , all idle : whores and knaves .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: I would with such perfection govern , sir ,
T’ excel the Golden Age .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: ’Save his Majesty !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Long live Gonzalo !

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: And do you mark me , sir ?

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Prithee , no more . Thou dost talk nothing to me .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: I do well believe your Highness , and did it to
minister occasion to these gentlemen , who are of
such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use
to laugh at nothing .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: ’Twas you we laughed at .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Who in this kind of merry fooling am
nothing to you . So you may continue , and laugh at
nothing still .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: What a blow was there given !

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: An it had not fallen flatlong .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: You are gentlemen of brave mettle . You
would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would
continue in it five weeks without changing .

stage.hi: Enter Ariel invisible , playing solemn music .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: We would so , and then go a-batfowling .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO , to Gonzalo
sp.l: Nay , good my lord , be not angry .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: No , I warrant you , I will not adventure my
discretion so weakly . Will you laugh me asleep ?
For I am very heavy .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Go sleep , and hear us .

stage.hi: All sink down asleep except Alonso , Antonio , and Sebastian .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: What , all so soon asleep ? I wish mine eyes
Would , with themselves , shut up my thoughts . I find
They are inclined to do so .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Please you , sir ,
Do not omit the heavy offer of it .
It seldom visits sorrow ; when it doth ,
It is a comforter .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: We two , my lord ,
Will guard your person while you take your rest ,
And watch your safety .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Thank you . Wondrous heavy .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: What a strange drowsiness possesses them !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: It is the quality o’ th’ climate .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Why
Doth it not then our eyelids sink ? I find
Not myself disposed to sleep .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Nor I . My spirits are nimble .
They fell together all , as by consent .
They dropped as by a thunderstroke . What might ,
Worthy Sebastian , O , what might — ? No more .
And yet methinks I see it in thy face
What thou shouldst be . Th’ occasion speaks thee , and
My strong imagination sees a crown
Dropping upon thy head .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: What , art thou waking ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Do you not hear me speak ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I do , and surely
It is a sleepy language , and thou speak’st
Out of thy sleep . What is it thou didst say ?
This is a strange repose , to be asleep
With eyes wide open — standing , speaking , moving —
And yet so fast asleep .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Noble Sebastian ,
Thou let’st thy fortune sleep , die rather , wink’st
Whiles thou art waking .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Thou dost snore distinctly .
There’s meaning in thy snores .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: I am more serious than my custom . You
Must be so too , if heed me ; which to do
Trebles thee o’er .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Well , I am standing water .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: I’ll teach you how to flow .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Do so . To ebb
Hereditary sloth instructs me .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: O ,
If you but knew how you the purpose cherish
Whiles thus you mock it , how in stripping it
You more invest it . Ebbing men indeed
Most often do so near the bottom run
By their own fear or sloth .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Prithee , say on .
The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim
A matter from thee , and a birth indeed
Which throes thee much to yield .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Thus , sir :
Although this lord of weak remembrance — this ,
Who shall be of as little memory
When he is earthed — hath here almost persuaded —
For he’s a spirit of persuasion , only
Professes to persuade — the King his son’s alive ,
’Tis as impossible that he’s undrowned
As he that sleeps here swims .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I have no hope
That he’s undrowned .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: O , out of that no hope
What great hope have you ! No hope that way is
Another way so high a hope that even
Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond ,
But doubt discovery there . Will you grant with me
That Ferdinand is drowned ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: He’s gone .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Then tell me ,
Who’s the next heir of Naples ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Claribel .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: She that is Queen of Tunis ; she that dwells
Ten leagues beyond man’s life ; she that from Naples
Can have no note , unless the sun were post —
The man i’ th’ moon’s too slow — till newborn chins
Be rough and razorable ; she that from whom
We all were sea-swallowed , though some cast again ,
And by that destiny to perform an act
Whereof what’s past is prologue , what to come
In yours and my discharge .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: What stuff is this ? How say you ?
’Tis true my brother’s daughter’s Queen of Tunis ,
So is she heir of Naples , ’twixt which regions
There is some space .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: A space whose ev’ry cubit
Seems to cry out “ How shall that Claribel
Measure us back to Naples ? Keep in Tunis
And let Sebastian wake . ” Say this were death
That now hath seized them , why , they were no worse
Than now they are . There be that can rule Naples
As well as he that sleeps , lords that can prate
As amply and unnecessarily
As this Gonzalo . I myself could make
A chough of as deep chat . O , that you bore
The mind that I do , what a sleep were this
For your advancement ! Do you understand me ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Methinks I do .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: And how does your content
Tender your own good fortune ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I remember
You did supplant your brother Prospero .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: True ,
And look how well my garments sit upon me ,
Much feater than before . My brother’s servants
Were then my fellows ; now they are my men .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: But , for your conscience ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Ay , sir , where lies that ? If ’twere a kibe ,
’Twould put me to my slipper , but I feel not
This deity in my bosom . Twenty consciences
That stand ’twixt me and Milan , candied be they
And melt ere they molest ! Here lies your brother ,
No better than the earth he lies upon .
If he were that which now he’s like — that’s dead —
Whom I with this obedient steel , three inches of it ,
Can lay to bed forever ; whiles you , doing thus ,
To the perpetual wink for aye might put
This ancient morsel , this Sir Prudence , who
Should not upbraid our course . For all the rest ,
They’ll take suggestion as a cat laps milk .
They’ll tell the clock to any business that
We say befits the hour .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Thy case , dear friend ,
Shall be my precedent : as thou got’st Milan ,
I’ll come by Naples . Draw thy sword . One stroke
Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest ,
And I the King shall love thee .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Draw together ,
And when I rear my hand , do you the like
To fall it on Gonzalo .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: O , but one word .

stage.hi: Enter Ariel , invisible , with music and song .

sp.speaker: ARIEL , to the sleeping Gonzalo
sp.l: My master through his art foresees the danger
That you , his friend , are in , and sends me forth —
For else his project dies — to keep them living .

lg.l: While you here do snoring lie ,
Open-eyed conspiracy
His time doth take .
If of life you keep a care ,
Shake off slumber and beware .
Awake , awake !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO , to Sebastian
sp.l: Then let us both be sudden .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , waking
sp.l: Now , good angels preserve the
King !

sp.speaker: ALONSO , to Sebastian
sp.l: Why , how now , ho ! Awake ? Why are you drawn ?
Wherefore this ghastly looking ?

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Sebastian
sp.l: What’s the matter ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Whiles we stood here securing your repose ,
Even now , we heard a hollow burst of bellowing
Like bulls , or rather lions . Did ’t not wake you ?
It struck mine ear most terribly .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: I heard nothing .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: O , ’twas a din to fright a monster’s ear ,
To make an earthquake . Sure , it was the roar
Of a whole herd of lions .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Heard you this , Gonzalo ?

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Upon mine honor , sir , I heard a humming ,
And that a strange one too , which did awake me .
I shaked you , sir , and cried . As mine eyes opened ,
I saw their weapons drawn . There was a noise ,
That’s verily . ’Tis best we stand upon our guard ,
Or that we quit this place . Let’s draw our weapons .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Lead off this ground , and let’s make further search
For my poor son .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Heavens keep him from these beasts ,
For he is , sure , i’ th’ island .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Lead away .

sp.speaker: ARIEL , aside
sp.l: Prospero my lord shall know what I have done .
So , king , go safely on to seek thy son .

stage.hi: Enter Caliban with a burden of wood .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: All the infections that the sun sucks up
From bogs , fens , flats , on Prosper fall and make him
By inchmeal a disease ! His spirits hear me ,
And yet I needs must curse . But they’ll nor pinch ,
Fright me with urchin-shows , pitch me i’ th’ mire ,
Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark
Out of my way , unless he bid ’em . But
For every trifle are they set upon me ,
Sometimes like apes , that mow and chatter at me
And after bite me ; then like hedgehogs , which
Lie tumbling in my barefoot way and mount
Their pricks at my footfall . Sometime am I
All wound with adders , who with cloven tongues
Do hiss me into madness . Lo , now , lo !
Here comes a spirit of his , and to torment me
For bringing wood in slowly . I’ll fall flat .
Perchance he will not mind me .

stage.hi: He lies down and covers himself with a cloak .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Here’s neither bush nor shrub to bear off
any weather at all . And another storm brewing ; I
hear it sing i’ th’ wind . Yond same black cloud , yond
huge one , looks like a foul bombard that would shed
his liquor . If it should thunder as it did before , I
know not where to hide my head . Yond same cloud
cannot choose but fall by pailfuls .
What have we here , a man or a fish ? Dead or
alive ? A fish , he smells like a fish — a very ancient
and fishlike smell , a kind of not-of-the-newest poor-John .
A strange fish . Were I in England now , as once
I was , and had but this fish painted , not a holiday
fool there but would give a piece of silver . There
would this monster make a man . Any strange beast
there makes a man . When they will not give a doit to
relieve a lame beggar , they will lay out ten to see a
dead Indian . Legged like a man , and his fins like
arms ! Warm , o’ my troth ! I do now let loose my
opinion , hold it no longer : this is no fish , but an
islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt .
Thunder . Alas , the storm is come again . My best
way is to creep under his gaberdine . There is no
other shelter hereabout . Misery acquaints a man
with strange bedfellows . I will here shroud till the
dregs of the storm be past .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: I shall no more to sea , to sea .
Here shall I die ashore —
This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man’s funeral .
Well , here’s my comfort .

lg.l: The master , the swabber , the boatswain , and I ,
The gunner and his mate ,
Loved Mall , Meg , and Marian , and Margery ,
But none of us cared for Kate .
For she had a tongue with a tang ,
Would cry to a sailor “ Go hang ! ”
She loved not the savor of tar nor of pitch ,
Yet a tailor might scratch her where’er she did itch .
Then to sea , boys , and let her go hang !

sp.l: This is a scurvy tune too . But here’s my comfort .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Do not torment me ! O !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: What’s the matter ? Have we devils here ? Do
you put tricks upon ’s with savages and men of Ind ?
Ha ? I have not scaped drowning to be afeard now
of your four legs , for it hath been said “ As proper a
man as ever went on four legs cannot make him
give ground , ” and it shall be said so again while
Stephano breathes at’ nostrils .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: The spirit torments me . O !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: This is some monster of the isle with four
legs , who hath got , as I take it , an ague . Where the
devil should he learn our language ? I will give him
some relief , if it be but for that . If I can recover him
and keep him tame and get to Naples with him ,
he’s a present for any emperor that ever trod on
neat’s leather .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Do not torment me , prithee . I’ll bring my
wood home faster .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: He’s in his fit now , and does not talk after
the wisest . He shall taste of my bottle . If he have
never drunk wine afore , it will go near to remove
his fit . If I can recover him and keep him tame , I will
not take too much for him . He shall pay for him that
hath him , and that soundly .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Thou dost me yet but little hurt . Thou wilt
anon ; I know it by thy trembling . Now Prosper
works upon thee .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Come on your ways . Open your mouth .
Here is that which will give language to you , cat .
Open your mouth . This will shake your shaking , I
can tell you , and that soundly . Caliban drinks . You
cannot tell who’s your friend . Open your chaps
again .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: I should know that voice . It should be — but
he is drowned , and these are devils . O , defend me !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Four legs and two voices — a most delicate
monster ! His forward voice now is to speak well of
his friend . His backward voice is to utter foul
speeches and to detract . If all the wine in my bottle
will recover him , I will help his ague . Come . Caliban drinks . Amen ! I will pour some in thy
other mouth .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Stephano !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Doth thy other mouth call me ? Mercy , mercy ,
this is a devil , and no monster ! I will leave him ; I
have no long spoon .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Stephano ! If thou be’st Stephano , touch me
and speak to me , for I am Trinculo — be not
afeard — thy good friend Trinculo .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: If thou be’st Trinculo , come forth . I’ll pull
thee by the lesser legs . If any be Trinculo’s legs ,
these are they .

stage.hi: He pulls him out from under Caliban’s cloak .

sp.l: Thou art very Trinculo indeed . How
cam’st thou to be the siege of this mooncalf ? Can
he vent Trinculos ?

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: I took him to be killed with a thunderstroke .
But art thou not drowned , Stephano ? I
hope now thou art not drowned . Is the storm
overblown ? I hid me under the dead mooncalf’s
gaberdine for fear of the storm . And art thou living ,
Stephano ? O Stephano , two Neapolitans scaped !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Prithee , do not turn me about . My stomach
is not constant .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN , aside
sp.l: These be fine things , an if they be not
sprites . That’s a brave god and bears celestial liquor .
I will kneel to him .

stage.hi: He crawls out from under the cloak .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO , to Trinculo
sp.l: How didst thou scape ? How
cam’st thou hither ? Swear by this bottle how thou
cam’st hither — I escaped upon a butt of sack , which
the sailors heaved o’erboard — by this bottle , which
I made of the bark of a tree with mine own hands ,
since I was cast ashore .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I’ll swear upon that bottle to be thy true
subject , for the liquor is not earthly .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO , to Trinculo
sp.l: Here . Swear then how thou
escapedst .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Swum ashore , man , like a duck . I can swim
like a duck , I’ll be sworn .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Here , kiss the book .
Though thou canst swim like a duck , thou art made
like a goose .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: O Stephano , hast any more of this ?

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: The whole butt , man . My cellar is in a rock
by th’ seaside , where my wine is hid . — How now ,
mooncalf , how does thine ague ?

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Hast thou not dropped from heaven ?

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Out o’ th’ moon , I do assure thee . I was the
man i’ th’ moon when time was .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I have seen thee in her , and I do adore thee .
My mistress showed me thee , and thy dog , and thy
bush .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Come , swear to that . Kiss the book . I will
furnish it anon with new contents . Swear .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: By this good light , this is a very shallow
monster . I afeard of him ? A very weak monster . The
man i’ th’ moon ? A most poor , credulous monster !
— Well drawn , monster , in good sooth !

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I’ll show thee every fertile inch o’ th’ island ,
and I will kiss thy foot . I prithee , be my god .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: By this light , a most perfidious and drunken
monster . When ’s god’s asleep , he’ll rob his bottle .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I’ll kiss thy foot . I’ll swear myself thy subject .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Come on , then . Down , and swear .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed
monster . A most scurvy monster . I could
find in my heart to beat him —

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Come , kiss .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: — but that the poor monster’s in drink . An
abominable monster .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I’ll show thee the best springs . I’ll pluck thee berries .
I’ll fish for thee and get thee wood enough .
A plague upon the tyrant that I serve .
I’ll bear him no more sticks , but follow thee ,
Thou wondrous man .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: A most ridiculous monster , to make a wonder
of a poor drunkard .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN , standing
sp.l: I prithee , let me bring thee where crabs grow ,
And I with my long nails will dig thee pignuts ,
Show thee a jay’s nest , and instruct thee how
To snare the nimble marmoset . I’ll bring thee
To clustering filberts , and sometimes I’ll get thee
Young scamels from the rock . Wilt thou go with me ?

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: I prithee now , lead the way without any
more talking . — Trinculo , the King and all our
company else being drowned , we will inherit here .
— Here , bear my bottle . — Fellow Trinculo , we’ll
fill him by and by again .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN sings drunkenly
sp.l: Farewell , master , farewell , farewell .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: A howling monster , a drunken monster .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN sings

lg.l: No more dams I’ll make for fish ,
Nor fetch in firing
At requiring ,
Nor scrape trenchering , nor wash dish .
’Ban , ’ban , Ca-caliban
Has a new master . Get a new man .

sp.l: Freedom , high-day ! High-day , freedom ! Freedom ,
high-day , freedom !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: O brave monster ! Lead the way .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: There be some sports are painful , and their labor
Delight in them sets off ; some kinds of baseness
Are nobly undergone ; and most poor matters
Point to rich ends . This my mean task
Would be as heavy to me as odious , but
The mistress which I serve quickens what’s dead
And makes my labors pleasures . O , she is
Ten times more gentle than her father’s crabbed ,
And he’s composed of harshness . I must remove
Some thousands of these logs and pile them up ,
Upon a sore injunction . My sweet mistress
Weeps when she sees me work , and says such baseness
Had never like executor . I forget ;
But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors ,
Most busiest when I do it .

stage.hi: Enter Miranda ; and Prospero at a distance , unobserved .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Alas now , pray you ,
Work not so hard . I would the lightning had
Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile .
Pray , set it down and rest you . When this burns
’Twill weep for having wearied you . My father
Is hard at study . Pray now , rest yourself .
He’s safe for these three hours .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: O most dear mistress ,
The sun will set before I shall discharge
What I must strive to do .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: If you’ll sit down ,
I’ll bear your logs the while . Pray , give me that .
I’ll carry it to the pile .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: No , precious creature ,
I had rather crack my sinews , break my back ,
Than you should such dishonor undergo
While I sit lazy by .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: It would become me
As well as it does you , and I should do it
With much more ease , for my good will is to it ,
And yours it is against .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: Poor worm , thou art infected .
This visitation shows it .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: You look wearily .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: No , noble mistress , ’tis fresh morning with me
When you are by at night . I do beseech you ,
Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers ,
What is your name ?

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Miranda . — O my father ,
I have broke your hest to say so !

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: Admired Miranda !
Indeed the top of admiration , worth
What’s dearest to the world ! Full many a lady
I have eyed with best regard , and many a time
Th’ harmony of their tongues hath into bondage
Brought my too diligent ear . For several virtues
Have I liked several women , never any
With so full soul but some defect in her
Did quarrel with the noblest grace she owed ,
And put it to the foil . But you , O you ,
So perfect and so peerless , are created
Of every creature’s best .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: I do not know
One of my sex , no woman’s face remember ,
Save , from my glass , mine own . Nor have I seen
More that I may call men than you , good friend ,
And my dear father . How features are abroad
I am skilless of , but by my modesty ,
The jewel in my dower , I would not wish
Any companion in the world but you ,
Nor can imagination form a shape
Besides yourself to like of . But I prattle
Something too wildly , and my father’s precepts
I therein do forget .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: I am in my condition
A prince , Miranda ; I do think a king —
I would , not so ! — and would no more endure
This wooden slavery than to suffer
The flesh-fly blow my mouth . Hear my soul speak :
The very instant that I saw you did
My heart fly to your service , there resides
To make me slave to it , and for your sake
Am I this patient log-man .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: Do you love me ?

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: O heaven , O Earth , bear witness to this sound ,
And crown what I profess with kind event
If I speak true ; if hollowly , invert
What best is boded me to mischief . I ,
Beyond all limit of what else i’ th’ world ,
Do love , prize , honor you .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: I am a fool
To weep at what I am glad of .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: Fair encounter
Of two most rare affections . Heavens rain grace
On that which breeds between ’em !

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: Wherefore weep you ?

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: At mine unworthiness , that dare not offer
What I desire to give , and much less take
What I shall die to want . But this is trifling ,
And all the more it seeks to hide itself ,
The bigger bulk it shows . Hence , bashful cunning ,
And prompt me , plain and holy innocence .
I am your wife if you will marry me .
If not , I’ll die your maid . To be your fellow
You may deny me , but I’ll be your servant
Whether you will or no .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: My mistress , dearest , and I thus humble ever .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA
sp.l: My husband , then ?

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: Ay , with a heart as willing
As bondage e’er of freedom . Here’s my hand .

sp.speaker: MIRANDA , clasping his hand
sp.l: And mine , with my heart in ’t . And now farewell
Till half an hour hence .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: A thousand thousand .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: So glad of this as they I cannot be ,
Who are surprised withal ; but my rejoicing
At nothing can be more . I’ll to my book ,
For yet ere suppertime must I perform
Much business appertaining .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO , to Trinculo
sp.l: Tell not me . When the butt is
out , we will drink water ; not a drop before . Therefore
bear up and board ’em . — Servant monster ,
drink to me .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Servant monster ? The folly of this island !
They say there’s but five upon this isle ; we are three
of them . If th’ other two be brained like us , the state
totters .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Drink , servant monster , when I bid thee .
Thy eyes are almost set in thy head .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Where should they be set else ? He were a
brave monster indeed if they were set in his tail .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: My man-monster hath drowned his tongue
in sack . For my part , the sea cannot drown me . I
swam , ere I could recover the shore , five-and-thirty
leagues off and on , by this light . — Thou shalt be my
lieutenant , monster , or my standard .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Your lieutenant , if you list . He’s no
standard .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: We’ll not run , Monsieur Monster .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Nor go neither . But you’ll lie like dogs , and
yet say nothing neither .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Mooncalf , speak once in thy life , if thou
be’st a good mooncalf .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: How does thy Honor ? Let me lick thy shoe . I’ll
not serve him ; he is not valiant .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Thou liest , most ignorant monster . I am in
case to justle a constable . Why , thou debauched
fish , thou ! Was there ever man a coward that hath
drunk so much sack as I today ? Wilt thou tell a
monstrous lie , being but half a fish and half a
monster ?

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Lo , how he mocks me ! Wilt thou let him , my
lord ?

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: “ Lord , ” quoth he ? That a monster should be
such a natural !

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Lo , lo again ! Bite him to death , I prithee .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Trinculo , keep a good tongue in your head .
If you prove a mutineer , the next tree . The poor
monster’s my subject , and he shall not suffer
indignity .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I thank my noble lord . Wilt thou be pleased
to harken once again to the suit I made to thee ?

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Marry , will I . Kneel and repeat it . I will
stand , and so shall Trinculo .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN , kneeling
sp.l: As I told thee before , I am subject
to a tyrant , a sorcerer , that by his cunning hath
cheated me of the island .

sp.speaker: ARIEL , in Trinculo’s voice
sp.l: Thou liest .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN , to Trinculo
sp.l: Thou liest , thou jesting monkey ,
thou . He stands . I would my valiant master would
destroy thee . I do not lie .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Trinculo , if you trouble him any more in ’s
tale , by this hand , I will supplant some of your
teeth .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Why , I said nothing .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Mum then , and no more .
Proceed .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: I say by sorcery he got this isle ;
From me he got it . If thy Greatness will ,
Revenge it on him , for I know thou dar’st ,
But this thing dare not .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: That’s most certain .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Thou shalt be lord of it , and I’ll serve thee .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: How now shall this be compassed ? Canst
thou bring me to the party ?

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Yea , yea , my lord . I’ll yield him thee asleep ,
Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head .

sp.speaker: ARIEL , in Trinculo’s voice
sp.l: Thou liest . Thou canst not .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: What a pied ninny’s this ! — Thou scurvy patch ! —
I do beseech thy Greatness , give him blows
And take his bottle from him . When that’s gone ,
He shall drink naught but brine , for I’ll not show him
Where the quick freshes are .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Trinculo , run into no further danger . Interrupt
the monster one word further , and by this
hand , I’ll turn my mercy out o’ doors and make a
stockfish of thee .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Why , what did I ? I did nothing . I’ll go
farther off .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Didst thou not say he lied ?

sp.speaker: ARIEL , in Trinculo’s voice
sp.l: Thou liest .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Do I so ? Take thou that .
As you like this , give me the lie another time .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: I did not give the lie ! Out o’ your wits and
hearing too ? A pox o’ your bottle ! This can sack and
drinking do . A murrain on your monster , and the
devil take your fingers !

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Now forward with your tale .
Prithee , stand further off .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Beat him enough . After a little time
I’ll beat him too .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Stand farther .
Come , proceed .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Why , as I told thee , ’tis a custom with him
I’ th’ afternoon to sleep . There thou mayst brain him ,
Having first seized his books , or with a log
Batter his skull , or paunch him with a stake ,
Or cut his weasand with thy knife . Remember
First to possess his books , for without them
He’s but a sot , as I am , nor hath not
One spirit to command . They all do hate him
As rootedly as I . Burn but his books .
He has brave utensils — for so he calls them —
Which , when he has a house , he’ll deck withal .
And that most deeply to consider is
The beauty of his daughter . He himself
Calls her a nonpareil . I never saw a woman
But only Sycorax my dam and she ;
But she as far surpasseth Sycorax
As great’st does least .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Is it so brave a lass ?

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Ay , lord , she will become thy bed , I warrant ,
And bring thee forth brave brood .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Monster , I will kill this man . His daughter
and I will be king and queen — save our Graces ! —
and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys . — Dost
thou like the plot , Trinculo ?

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: Excellent .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Give me thy hand . I am sorry I beat thee .
But while thou liv’st , keep a good tongue in thy
head .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Within this half hour will he be asleep .
Wilt thou destroy him then ?

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Ay , on mine honor .

sp.speaker: ARIEL , aside
sp.l: This will I tell my master .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Thou mak’st me merry . I am full of pleasure .
Let us be jocund . Will you troll the catch
You taught me but whilere ?

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: At thy request , monster , I will do reason ,
any reason . — Come on , Trinculo , let us sing .
Flout ’em and cout ’em
And scout ’em and flout ’em !
Thought is free .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: That’s not the tune .

stage.hi: Ariel plays the tune on a tabor and pipe .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: What is this same ?

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: This is the tune of our catch played by the
picture of Nobody .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO , to the invisible musician
sp.l: If thou be’st a
man , show thyself in thy likeness . If thou be’st a
devil , take ’t as thou list .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: O , forgive me my sins !

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: He that dies pays all debts . — I defy thee ! —
Mercy upon us !

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Art thou afeard ?

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: No , monster , not I .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: Be not afeard . The isle is full of noises ,
Sounds and sweet airs that give delight and hurt not .
Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments
Will hum about mine ears , and sometimes voices
That , if I then had waked after long sleep ,
Will make me sleep again ; and then , in dreaming ,
The clouds methought would open , and show riches
Ready to drop upon me , that when I waked
I cried to dream again .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: This will prove a brave kingdom to me ,
where I shall have my music for nothing .

sp.speaker: CALIBAN
sp.l: When Prospero is destroyed .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: That shall be by and by . I remember the
story .

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: The sound is going away . Let’s follow it , and
after do our work .

sp.speaker: STEPHANO
sp.l: Lead , monster . We’ll follow . — I would I
could see this taborer . He lays it on . Wilt come ?

sp.speaker: TRINCULO
sp.l: I’ll follow , Stephano .

div.head: Scene 3

stage.hi: Enter Alonso , Sebastian , Antonio , Gonzalo , Adrian , Francisco , etc.

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: By ’r lakin , I can go no further , sir .
My old bones aches . Here’s a maze trod indeed
Through forthrights and meanders . By your patience ,
I needs must rest me .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Old lord , I cannot blame thee .
Who am myself attached with weariness
To th’ dulling of my spirits . Sit down and rest .
Even here I will put off my hope and keep it
No longer for my flatterer . He is drowned
Whom thus we stray to find , and the sea mocks
Our frustrate search on land . Well , let him go .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO , aside to Sebastian
sp.l: I am right glad that he’s so out of hope .
Do not , for one repulse , forgo the purpose
That you resolved t’ effect .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN , aside to Antonio
sp.l: The next advantage
Will we take throughly .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO , aside to Sebastian
sp.l: Let it be tonight ;
For now they are oppressed with travel , they
Will not nor cannot use such vigilance
As when they are fresh .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN , aside to Antonio
sp.l: I say tonight . No more .

stage.hi: , and enter Prospero on the top invisible .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: What harmony is this ? My good friends , hark .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Marvelous sweet music !

stage.hi: Enter several strange shapes , bringing in a banquet , and dance about it with gentle actions of salutations .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Give us kind keepers , heavens ! What were these ?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: A living drollery ! Now I will believe
That there are unicorns , that in Arabia
There is one tree , the phoenix’ throne , one phoenix
At this hour reigning there .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: I’ll believe both ;
And what does else want credit , come to me
And I’ll be sworn ’tis true . Travelers ne’er did lie ,
Though fools at home condemn ’em .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: If in Naples
I should report this now , would they believe me ?
If I should say I saw such islanders —
For , certes , these are people of the island —
Who , though they are of monstrous shape , yet note
Their manners are more gentle , kind , than of
Our human generation you shall find
Many , nay , almost any .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: Honest lord ,
Thou hast said well , for some of you there present
Are worse than devils .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: I cannot too much muse
Such shapes , such gesture , and such sound , expressing —
Although they want the use of tongue — a kind
Of excellent dumb discourse .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: Praise in departing .

stage.hi: Inviting the King , etc. , to eat , the shapes depart .

sp.speaker: FRANCISCO
sp.l: They vanished strangely .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: No matter , since
They have left their viands behind , for we have stomachs .
Will ’t please you taste of what is here ?

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: Not I .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: Faith , sir , you need not fear . When we were boys ,
Who would believe that there were mountaineers
Dewlapped like bulls , whose throats had hanging at ’em
Wallets of flesh ? Or that there were such men
Whose heads stood in their breasts ? Which now we find
Each putter-out of five for one will bring us
Good warrant of .

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: I will stand to and feed .
Although my last , no matter , since I feel
The best is past . Brother , my lord the Duke ,
Stand to , and do as we .

stage.hi: Alonso , Sebastian , and Antonio move toward the table .
and lightning . Enter Ariel , like a Harpy , claps his wings upon the table ,
with a quaint device the banquet vanishes .

sp.speaker: ARIEL as Harpy
sp.l: You are three men of sin , whom Destiny ,
That hath to instrument this lower world
And what is in ’t , the never-surfeited sea
Hath caused to belch up you , and on this island ,
Where man doth not inhabit , you ’mongst men
Being most unfit to live . I have made you mad ;
And even with such-like valor , men hang and drown
Their proper selves .

stage.hi: Alonso , Sebastian , and Antonio draw their swords .

sp.l: You fools , I and my fellows
Are ministers of Fate . The elements
Of whom your swords are tempered may as well
Wound the loud winds or with bemocked-at stabs
Kill the still-closing waters as diminish
One dowl that’s in my plume . My fellow ministers
Are like invulnerable . If you could hurt ,
Your swords are now too massy for your strengths
And will not be uplifted . But remember —
For that’s my business to you — that you three
From Milan did supplant good Prospero ,
Exposed unto the sea , which hath requit it ,
Him and his innocent child , for which foul deed ,
The powers — delaying , not forgetting — have
Incensed the seas and shores , yea , all the creatures
Against your peace . Thee of thy son , Alonso ,
They have bereft ; and do pronounce by me
Ling’ring perdition , worse than any death
Can be at once , shall step by step attend
You and your ways , whose wraths to guard you from —
Which here , in this most desolate isle , else falls
Upon your heads — is nothing but heart’s sorrow
And a clear life ensuing .

div.stage:
Then ,
to soft music , enter the shapes again , and dance , with mocks and mows , and carrying out the table .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , aside
sp.l: Bravely the figure of this Harpy hast thou
Performed , my Ariel . A grace it had , devouring .
Of my instruction hast thou nothing bated
In what thou hadst to say . So , with good life
And observation strange , my meaner ministers
Their several kinds have done . My high charms work ,
And these mine enemies are all knit up
In their distractions . They now are in my power ;
And in these fits I leave them while I visit
Young Ferdinand , whom they suppose is drowned ,
And his and mine loved darling .

sp.speaker: GONZALO , to Alonso
sp.l: I’ th’ name of something holy , sir , why stand you
In this strange stare ?

sp.speaker: ALONSO
sp.l: O , it is monstrous , monstrous !
Methought the billows spoke and told me of it ;
The winds did sing it to me , and the thunder ,
That deep and dreadful organ pipe , pronounced
The name of Prosper . It did bass my trespass .
Therefor my son i’ th’ ooze is bedded , and
I’ll seek him deeper than e’er plummet sounded ,
And with him there lie mudded .

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: But one fiend at a time ,
I’ll fight their legions o’er .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: I’ll be thy second .

sp.speaker: GONZALO
sp.l: All three of them are desperate . Their great guilt ,
Like poison given to work a great time after ,
Now ’gins to bite the spirits . I do beseech you
That are of suppler joints , follow them swiftly
And hinder them from what this ecstasy
May now provoke them to .

sp.speaker: ADRIAN
sp.l: Follow , I pray you .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO , to Ferdinand
sp.l: If I have too austerely punished you ,
Your compensation makes amends , for I
Have given you here a third of mine own life ,
Or that for which I live ; who once again
I tender to thy hand . All thy vexations
Were but my trials of thy love , and thou
Hast strangely stood the test . Here afore heaven
I ratify this my rich gift . O Ferdinand ,
Do not smile at me that I boast of her ,
For thou shalt find she will outstrip all praise
And make it halt behind her .

sp.speaker: FERDINAND
sp.l: I do believe it
Against an oracle .

sp.speaker: PROSPERO
sp.l: Then , as my gift and thine own acquisition
Worthily purchased , take my daughter . But
If thou dost break her virgin-knot before
All sanctimonious ceremonies may
With full and holy rite be ministered ,
No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall
